required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study to Determine Safety and Effectiveness of Tadalafil on Prostate Related Sex Organ/Urinary Tract Problems
clinical_study.official_title: A Multicenter, Parallel-Arm, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Tadalafil Administered Once Daily to Men With Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms Secondary to Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia

brief_summary.textblock: Study to look at safety and effectiveness of different doses of tadalafil on prostate related genital/urinary tract problems.

primary_outcome.measure: International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) sum total of questions 1-7

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluate different domains of the IPSS sums along with other questionnaires such as the LUTS GAQ and BII.
Evaluate safety by PSA levels and postvoid residual volume (PVR)

arm_group.description: Placebo run in followed by 5 mg treatment phase 1 and then 20 mg treatment phase 2 which both include a placebo control.
Treatment phase 1 includes 5 mg tadalafil 6 weeks then treatment phase 2 which includes 20 mg tadalafil for 6 weeks.

intervention.description: Treatment phase 1 includes 5 mg tadalafil tablet taken by mouth once a day for 6 weeks then treatment phase 2 which includes 20 mg tadalafil tablet taken by mouth once a day for 6 weeks.
Placebo tablet run in followed by placebo treatment period with one tablet taken by mouth once a day for twelve weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 6 month history of lower urinary tract symptoms either obstructive and/or irritative secondary to prostate related problems as diagnosed by a urologist.
- Stopped using treatments at least four weeks prior to study and agree to not use any other treatments during the study.
- Meet required prostate symptom score and urine flow rate.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Serum prostate specific antigen (PSA) greater than 10 (between 4 and 10, inclusive, without a negative biopsy w/in the last 6 months.
- Prostate removal and various other pelvic surgeries.
- Neurological disease or condition known to affect the bladder.
- Clinical evidence of prostate cancer, urinary tract inflammation or infection, including prostatitis.
- Have taken medications such as nitrates, finasteride, or dutasteride within the year.
